title: James Nasmyth, Engineer: An Autobiography
author: Nasmyth, James
snippet: His eldestson was long a member of Parliament for the county of Peebles; he was,besides, a famous botanist, having studied under Linnaeus, Among theinter-marriages of the family were those with the Bruces of Lethen, theStewarts of Traquhair, the Murrays of Stanhope, the Pringles of Clifton,the Murrays of Philiphaugh, the Keiths (of the Earl Marischal's family),the Andersons of St. Germains, the Marjoribanks of Lees, and others.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: It formerly belonged to the Pringles of Whytbank, and is now the property of Lord Polwarth.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The road now enters Selkirkshire, and conducts the tourist to Selkirk, close to which is the Haining, the beautiful seat of the Pringles of Clifton.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Galashiels proper is a burgh of barony, under the family of Gala, which now bears the name of Scott, though representing the ancient Pringles — the ancestor of Mr. Scott having married the heiress of that baronial house, and succeeded to its fortunes iu 1 023.

title: Lay morals, and other papers,

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: I prefer the girl's father dead ; and the question is how in that case could Lieutenant George Murray get his order to apprehend and his power to sell her in marriage ? Or ... might Lieutenant G. be her tutor, and the fugitive to the Pringles, and on the discovery of her whereabouts hastily married ? A good legal note on these points is very ardently desired by me ; it will be the corner-stone of my novel.

title: Journal of a lady of quality;
author: Schaw, Janet
snippet: The first he called "Rowland," after his father's estate in Scotland, which had some years before passed into the hands of the Pringles; and the other "Hunthill," the name of the estate of his Scottish relative, Henry Rutherfurd, which lay on the right bank of the Jed, extending north to the neighborhood of Jedburgh.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Mr. James (the author of Richelieu) and his lady, who this season lived at Maxpoffle, and Mr. Archdeacon  Williams, who was spending his vacation at Melrose,  were welcome additions — and frequently so — to his accustomed circle of the Scotts of Harden, the Pringles of Whytbank and Clifton, the Russells of Ashestiel, the Brewsters, and the Fergussons.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Kers, Scotts, Pringles, Elliots, they all sleep here each in their own antique aisle the same venerable escutcheon carved or molten above the dust of every succeeding generation.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Mildred was gone to London for Easter: Carl Nilsson was in Germany: the Pringles, like most other people, were out of town.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: There was always some " ploy " forward  with the Pringles, and Joanna, who in these ways had never been young before, entered into everything like a schoolgirl.

title: Lady Jean's Son. A novel
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: IfDavie should be detained elsewhere, other of ourcounsel may turn up ; one of her friends, thePringles, is on the list, and so is her kinsman, LordAlemoor.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: Little is known of its history,except that it belonged to the Pringles and was built about 1535; butthe walls, seven feet thick, the dungeon above the cattle cellar, enteredonly by a small square hole in the middle of the kitchen flooroverhead, the narrow shot-windows, and the high arched roof of stone,all indicate that the Baron of Smailholm was a man of strength andstrife.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: This was followed by the transference quoadsacra of some of the disjecta membra of Yarrow onTweedside to the new church and parish of Caddonfoot, erected mainly through the liberality of thePringles of Whytbank, and found to be verymuch for the convenience of the inhabitants ofthe district.
